Well, it is the international norm.

Most modern democracies use proportional voting systems, and I think as one goes deeper into this debate--I think Steve fingered a very clear paradox, which is if you have a competitive district, even if it is representative in that one election of a certain point of view, it variously won't be representative of that the next time.
And certain kinds of representation, we probably want to have pretty consistently represented or else people feel, you know, less connected to their legislatures.

I think proportional systems are often thought to be sort of one thing, and people think it's like--`Oh, that's what--didn't they use that in Italy and that has, like, you know, 400 parties elected and'--you know.
And the reality is, there's a whole family of systems, some of which open the door a lot less to multiparty democracy than others.

The one that we think particularly speaks to this debate--and as we look at a kind of measure that would plausibly be on the ballot and I think be a strong one in the short term would be what Illinois used to use.

They had three-seat constituencies, so they had three representatives in a district, rather than one, and they used a voting method--their particular method was cumulative voting, but it's one of these proportional systems where it took about a third of the vote to win one of the three seats and a majority to win two out of three.
And what you typically saw was one party winning two seats, the other party winning one, third parties being around and able to hold the major parties accountable.

But you did balance more of the goals that people are seeking, which is voter choice and sort of continuity of representation, more representation of some of the interests that our callers have been mentioning.
